children.value: steps run as a Node.js application which you can debug using standard tools for Node.js applications.
In this guide you will learn how to debug some code using:
As an example let’s use the following code snippet in a

const { createFilePath } = require("gatsby-source-filesystem")

exports.onCreateNode = args => {
  const { actions, Node } = args

  if (Node.internal.type === "MarkdownRemark") {
    const { createNodeField } = actions

    const value = createFilePath({ node, getNode })
    createNodeField({
      name: `slug`,
      node,
      value,
    })
  }
}
There is a bug in this code and using it will produce the error below:

TypeError: Cannot read property 'internal' of undefined

  - gatsby-node.js:6 Object.exports.onCreateNode.args [as onCreateNode]
    D:/dev/blog-v2/gatsby-node.js:6:12

hProperties.aria-label: vs code debugger auto config permalink

children.value: If you use VS Code and its integrated terminal, you can configure it to automatically create the debug config for you.
into the search bar. Make sure the

children.alt: Search for on debug and set attach to enable

children.value: Using VS Code’s integrated terminal run

hProperties.aria-label: vs code debugger manual config permalink

children.value: Using built in debuggers in code editors is very convenient. You will be able to skip a lot of setup needed to use Chrome DevTools. You will also be able to put breakpoints in the same view you write your code.
We won’t go in depth here about how to debug in VS Code - for that you can check the
. We will however share a launch configuration needed to run and debug Gatsby:

{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Gatsby develop",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/gatsby/dist/bin/gatsby",
      "args": ["develop"],
      "stopOnEntry": false,
      "runtimeArgs": ["--nolazy"],
      "sourceMaps": false
    },
    {
      "name": "Gatsby build",
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "protocol": "inspector",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/gatsby/dist/bin/gatsby",
      "args": ["build"],
      "stopOnEntry": false,
      "runtimeArgs": ["--nolazy"],
      "sourceMaps": false
    }
  ]
}
command from VS Code you can see the final result:

hProperties.aria-label: running gatsby with the inspect flag permalink

children.value: In your project directory instead of running
node --inspect-brk --no-lazy node_modules/gatsby/dist/bin/gatsby develop
will enable Node’s inspector agent which will allow you to connect a debugger. It will also pause execution until the debugger is connected and then wait for you to resume it.
- this will force Node’s V8 engine to disable lazy compilation and will help with using breakpoints.
in Chrome browser and connect to a “Remote Target” by clicking the
You should see Chrome DevTools start and that code execution is paused at the start of the

Right now you can’t see your files in Sources. You need to add those using the “Add folder to workspace” button and pick the directory with the code you want to debug. If you want to debug code in your
or your local plugins, pick your project directory. If you want debug the
package you will have to pick the
This example has problematic code in your local
file, so let’s add the directory containing it to Sources. You should have a directory with your code in the left pane:
Let’s go ahead and add a breakpoint just before the place that the error is thrown. To add a breakpoint navigate to
and left click on a line number:

Now you can resume code execution by clicking the “resume” icon in the DevTools debug toolbar (or press F8 on your keyboard). Gatsby will start running and pause once it reaches a breakpoint, allowing you to inspect variables:
To inspect variables you can hover your mouse over them or go to the
section in the right-hand pane (either collapse the “Call Stack” section or scroll through it to the bottom).
and to figure out why, let’s go backwards.
so let’s examine that by hovering
We can now see the problem -
. So this small typographic mistake was causing our code to fail. Adjusting our code to use a lowercase
fixes the problem and we did that without adding tons of

You can successfully debug your code using Chrome DevTools but using it isn’t really that convenient. There are a lot of steps you need to do manually every time you want to use debugger, thankfully there are other methods that make it simpler to start such as the ones outlined above.
This was an introduction to Node.js debugging. Using information from this section you can setup debugging in your code editor or IDE of choice (if it supports node debugging).
a code editor or IDE to debug Node.js applications. Using Chrome DevTools is usually a safe fallback.
Debugging isn’t the only thing you can do in Chrome DevTools. Once you connect to DevTools you can use CPU or memory profilers. Check the
Debugging with Node.js - Paul Irish talk at Node Summit 2017
